fields.label_text:
This collection of silver slices, all commissioned over a period of twenty years by Professor Benton Seymour Rabinovitch FRS, is proof of the skill and diversity of contemporary silversmiths.  Each artist craftsman has responded to the familiar functional form of the slice in an individual way, producing an astonishingly diverse range of interpretations.  Each piece becomes an enchanting, decorative work of art. Professor Rabinovitch established a close rapport with each artist, always encouraging a freedom of creative expression.  The response of these silversmiths has been not only to be strikingly imaginative but also to honour him by giving him their best work.

This collection is testimony to the significant contribution that one individual can make to supporting the craft of silversmithing.  After commissioning work from some of the most illustrious names in British and North American silversmithing, Professor Rabinovitch has very generously donated his entire collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, through the American Friends of the V&A.

fields.descriptive_line: Silver, USA, Houston, Texas, 1995, designed and made by Val Link

fields.name: The Rabinovitch Collection
fields.venue: Victoria and Albert Museum, The Whiteley Silver Galleries

fields.physical_description: The blade is of triangular shape, orientated to a saw tooth tip at the left side;  it has a swept up and over curve along the right edge, in a wave / surf form.  The upsweep is brightly peened, but at the top and bottom of the blade are polished 16 gauge sheet and a re chisel engraved with a fleeing school of fish.  The handle is a realistic shel- formed shark whose mouth is half buried in the rolling wave.  The dorsal and two side fins are cast and soldered to the body.  It is made of 18 gauge sheet and has an almost invisible seam along the belly.  The fins are added to the bottom.
fields.label:
This collection of silver slices, all commissioned over a period of twenty years by Professor Benton Seymour Rabinovitch FRS, is proof of the skill and diversity of contemporary silversmiths.  Each artist craftsman has responded to the familiar functional form of the slice in an individual way, producing an astonishingly diverse range of interpretations.  Each piece becomes an enchanting, decorative work of art. Professor Rabinovitch established a close rapport with each artist, always encouraging a freedom of creative expression.  The response of these silversmiths has been not only to be strikingly imaginative but also to honour him by giving him their best work.

This collection is testimony to the significant contribution that one individual can make to supporting the craft of silversmithing.  After commissioning work from some of the most illustrious names in British and North American silversmithing, Professor Rabinovitch has very generously donated his entire collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, through the American Friends of the V&A. [2005]
fields.public_access_description: The design of this server has immediate impact. The menacing shark handle and the sweeping wave-like triangular blade are strongly contrasted through the disparity in finish, the blade with a higher reflective polish than the handle. The smooth, sinuous lines of the shark deftly capture the fluidity of movement. Shell-formed with dorsal and side fines cast and soldered onto the body, the handle is technically unusual. Contrasting the smooth surface of the shark the blade is brightly peened along the upsweep and chisel-engraved along the tip with a fleeing school of fish. The shark design is echoed in the saw-tooth tip. The drama and originality of this piece do not compromise its practicality; the solid handle fits comfortably in the hand, and the blade is generously proportioned.
fields.exhibition_history: The Rabinovitch Collection (Victoria and Albert Museum 19/10/2005-25/01/2007)
fields.bibliography: Benton Seymour Rabinovitch and Helen Clifford, <u>Contemporary Silver, commissioning, designing, collecting</u>, London, Merrell, 2000, pp. 128-9. ill. ISBN.1858941040
fields.credit: Given by the American Friends of the V&A through the generosity of Professor B. Seymour Rabinovitch
fields.history_note: Historical significance: Link prides his work on its innovation, using functionality as a platform for creative designs. Technical precision is paramount in his sculpturally simple concepts. Link's greatest aim is to unite the "aesthetic, functional and technical aspects of design composition", which he does with flair and grace.
fields.historical_context_note: Part of a collection of fish slices commissioned by Professor Rabinovitch from contemporary North American and British makers.
